newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE sees no danger to exchange if Labour wins election.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE sees no danger to exchange if Labour wins election.

text.p: Leading derivatives exchange LIFFE is not scared by the prospect of a Labour government in Britain even though it would bring an end to the rule of a Conservative administration which has kept regulation to a minimum.
LIFFE chief executive Daniel Hodson said on Monday he did not expect any negative changes in terms of regulatory framework or industry-related fiscal measures if Labour were in power.

Hodson, speaking in an interview with Reuters, said the exchange had been concerned about retaining a self-regulatory framework and ensuring authorities understood any type of transaction tax could drive business out of Britain.
"We're comfortable that whatever government there is has recognised our contribution and is not planning at any rate to make any changes which are inimical to us," Hodson told Reuters.
Hodson said LIFFE had been keen to emphasise to Labour officials that the current regulatory environment, in which LIFFE patrols itself, had operated well.
He said LIFFE, the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange, had also worked hard to ensure that the ruling Conservatives also understood this.

He said he had not received any "copper bottom" guarantees from Labour that it would not introduce more stringent regulation or fiscal measures, but that in "private conversations" the exchange had been reassured.

"We have done a lot of work in talking to senior members of the government and to individual MPs (members of parliament) about what we do here and I think there is a much better understanding of where we fit into the financial services industry," Hodson said.
London's financial markets have enjoyed brisk business and a high degree of self-regulation under the Conservatives, in power since 1979. A general election must be held by May 22.
But LIFFE has been keen to forge warm relations with Labour as well. Labour's economic spokesman, Gordon Brown, used LIFFE as a forum to deliver a key speech on policy last November.
Hodson said potential deficiencies in its self-regulatory operations, if there were any, had been tightened in the post-Barings era.
"What Barings did do is it made exchanges and regulators focus much more on market risk -- systemic and also the risk associated with the involvement of individual players in the market place."
One facet of the Barings scandal involved the buildup of enormous positions by rogue trader Nick Leeson.

"At LIFFE we do not have a formal large position reporting department per se but we do believe that in terms of the practical effects of what we do at the moment, that we do as good a job as any other exchange which has large positions reporting," Hodson said.
He said the monitoring the exchange had done had not shown any "life-threatening" instances of large positions which the participants could not explain.
"We always get answers. If we don't then I'd be told and I can't think off hand recently of any situation where I've had to use my authority (to get to the bottom of a position)."
